docs.lead_paragraph: There has always been a debate over the destiny of this nation between those who believed they were entitled to govern because of their station in life, and those who believed that the people were sovereign. That distinction remains as strong as ever today. In every race this November, the question voters must answer is, How do we make sure that political power is used for the benefit of the many, rather than the few? For well over a year, the Bush administration has used its power in the wrong way. In 2000, I argued that the Bush-Cheney ticket was being bankrolled by ''a new generation of special interests, power brokers who would want nothing better than a pliant president who would bend public policy to suit their purposes and profits.'' Some considered this warning anti-business. It was nothing of the sort. I believe now, as I said then, that ''when powerful interests try to take advantage of the American people, it's often other businesses that are hurt in the process'' -- most of all, smaller companies that play by the rules.
docs.abstract: Al Gore Op-Ed article says there has always been debate over American destiny between those who believe they are entitled by status to govern and those who believe people are sovereign, and that distinction remains as strong as ever; urges voters this November to take government back from the greedy; adds that Pres Bush ought to be leading effort against corporate wrongdoers (M)
docs.snippet: There has always been a debate over the destiny of this nation between those who believed they were entitled to govern because of their station in life, and those who believed that the people were sovereign. That distinction remains as strong as ever...

docs.lead_paragraph: An awful lot of the best and brightest 17-year-olds want to be doctors. Despite the constraints of H.M.O.'s and the costs of malpractice insurance, the letters M.D. continue to bring prestige and prosperity to the names that are attached to them. That's why in the nation's elite colleges of arts and sciences -- including the University of Chicago, Cornell University and the University of Virginia -- 20 to 30 percent of first-year students identify themselves as pre-med. Within four years, of course, their ranks will be depleted -- only 10 percent will apply to medical school. Some drift away when they discover a new interest or find that they don't have the fire in their belly for a career in medicine. Others get derailed by the rigorous pre-med requirements -- a year of biology, general chemistry, organic chemistry, physics and, for some medical schools, calculus.
docs.snippet: An awful lot of the best and brightest 17-year-olds want to be doctors. Despite the constraints of H.M.O.'s and the costs of malpractice insurance, the letters M.D. continue to bring prestige and prosperity to the names that are attached to them....

docs.lead_paragraph: Picture a cliff plunging nearly a mile straight down into a thick blanket of green rain forest. Beyond it is the Gulf of Thailand, where on a late cloudless afternoon invisible fishing boats score tiny V's into the glassy surface. The mountain's edge of this place -- Bokor, in southern Cambodia -- is marked by a stone balustrade, once the breathtaking patio of a 1920's French hotel and casino that is now a charred, bullet-pocked shell. The sandbags of machine-gun nests abandoned by the Khmer Rouge have burst, and silicon stalactites leech from the remaining balconies. With relative peace restored to Cambodia in recent years, the surrounding bush is quickly reclaiming the place. Earlier in the day, fresh tiger droppings laced with telltale pig bones were spotted along the road. Now, as the sun drops toward the horizon, thousands of red butterflies suddenly arrive, pulsing in and out of the cavernous hotel, giving it a Marquezian sense of distant hope.
docs.abstract: Jack Hitt article on WildAid, which helps poor countries like Cambodia enforce protections on endangered species by paying extra money to state-employed rangers and training them in effecive Western military and law-enforcement tactics; its approach is economically comprehensive as well as aggressive, tracking all stages in illegal wildlife market, converting regular poachers to more legitimate careers like mushroom farming and paying them to informe on other poachers; annual budget is only about $2.5 million, $1 million coming from philanthropy run by Suwanna Gauntlett, heiress who founded organization with Pete Knights, Steve Trent and Steve Galster; WildAid raid in Cambodia rescues array of captured wildlife; photos (L)

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Re ''Senate Kills Plan for Drug Benefits Through Medicare'' (front page, Aug. 1): The elderly are not the only ones who need prescription drug coverage. I'm an otherwise healthy woman in her 40's who must take 8 to 10 treatments a day for Crohn's disease. My son takes a drug for attention deficit disorder.

headline.main: Drug Prices: Shame of a Nation

docs.abstract: Sharon Ford letter asks why Congress does not consider disabled people like herself, and the elderly, important enough to help by adding prescription drug benefit to Medicare

docs.lead_paragraph: Tally Last Week in Connecticut, New Jersey and New York. Senate 1. Prescription Drug Benefits: -- Vote on a plan to provide drug coverage to Medicare beneficiaries with low incomes or high drug costs. Failed, with 49 in favor and 50 opposed (far short of the 60-vote majority needed), July 31. 2. Generic Drugs: -- Vote on a bill that would reduce the ability of brand-name drug companies to delay the approval and marketing of generic products. Approved 78 to 21, July 31.
docs.abstract: Senate roll call (NY-NJ-Conn) on three votes: one to provide drug coverage to Medicare beneficiaries with low incomes or high drug costs, which failed, one to reduce ability of brand-name drug companies to delay approval and marketing of generic products, which passed, and one to give Pres Bush broad authority to negotiate global trade agreements that are largely immune from Congressional tinkering, which passed

docs.lead_paragraph: Determined to hold down labor costs in a weak and uncertain economy, the nation's employers slashed hours in July, cut overtime and limited hiring to a bare minimum, the Labor Department reported yesterday. The latest data raised fresh questions about the faltering economic recovery, suggesting that growth will be modest at best.

headline.main: Employment Data Raise Questions About Economic Recovery

docs.abstract: Labor Department reports employers slashed hours in July, cut overtime and limited hiring to bare minimum; latest data raise fresh questions about falling economic recovery, suggesting that growth will be modest at best; unemployment rate remained at 5.9 percent, same as June, as 86,000 people who might have been listed as unemployed and job hunting dropped out of labor force instead; total employment rose bare 6,000, to 130.8 million; employers cut average workweek by unusually large three-tenths of hour, to flat 34 hours; hourly wage rose in July by 4 cents, to $14.79 per hour, but from 12-month perspective, annual increase through July was 3.2 percent; Labor Sec Elaine L Chao says good news is that July's unemployment rate was essentially unchanged from previous month; Commerce Department reports factory orders fell sharply in June, indicating setback in industrial output after several months of improvement; says consumer spending rose in June by largest amount in two years and personal incomes increased by similarly smart amount; graph (M)
docs.snippet: Determined to hold down labor costs in a weak and uncertain economy, the nation's employers slashed hours in July, cut overtime and limited hiring to a bare minimum, the Labor Department reported yesterday.    The latest data raised fresh questions...

docs.lead_paragraph: The Cigna Corporation, a leading health insurer, said today that its profit fell 15 percent in the second quarter as investment losses doubled. Net income fell to $214 million, or $1.50 a share, compared with $252 million, or $1.66 a share, in the period a year earlier. Revenue rose 6.6 percent, to $4.97 billion from $4.66 billion.

headline.main: Cigna Profit Drops on Investment Losses

docs.abstract: Cigna Corp says its profit fell 15 percent in second quarter as investment losses doubled; net income fell to $214 milloin compared with $252 million year earlier; revenue rose 6.6 percent, to $4.97 billion from $4.66 billion (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: A front-page article on Thursday about a Senate vote against coverage of prescription drugs for some Medicare patients misstated the 10-year cost of the Senate Democrats' initial plan to cover all 40 million of them. The amount was $594 billion, not million.
docs.abstract: Correction of Aug 1 article: 10-year cost of Senate Democrats' initial plan to give drug coverage to all Medicare patients would have been $594 billion, not million

docs.lead_paragraph: New Yorkers, who already pay some of the highest prices in the nation for ambulance service, will soon be paying even more. The Fire Department, which provides two-thirds of the emergency ambulance service in the city, plans to increase its charges by 23 percent as early as September. The basic cost for a team of paramedics would jump by nearly $100, to $535.

headline.main: Fire Dept. to Raise the Rates For Its Ambulance Services

docs.abstract: New York City Fire Department, which provides two-thirds of emergency ambulance service in city, plans to increase its charges by 23 percent as early as September; increases are being imposed because of tightened city budget and as result of sharp cut in amount of money Medicare will pay for ambulance services; private companies will also raise fees (M)
